Authors:
Gualberto Rosado Rodriguez, Erica Sanchez Martínez, Sandra
L Maldonado Ramírez, Ernesto Otero Morales
Title:
Cultivable yeasts associated with demosponges from Puerto
Rico
Keywords:
fungi, marine sponges, Porifera, Saccharomyces cerevisiae,
Hortaea, Rhodotorula
Abstract:
Sponges are known for their symbiotic associations with
bacteria and to a lesser extent with fungi. It has been argued that the
association between fungi and sponges is not truly symbiotic, and fungal
presence is incidental. Nevertheless, a vertically transmitted
endosymbiotic yeast has been observed by transmission electron
microscopy in sponges of the genus Chondrilla. Our work focused on
documenting the presence of yeasts associated with marine sponges from
Puerto Rico. Sponge samples were taken from healthy mature colonies of
Ircinia strobilina, Tedania ignis, and Chondrilla caribensis. A total of
36 yeast morphotypes were isolated and analysed by sequencing the
nuclear ribosomal ITS region. Saccharomyces cerevisiae, was isolated
from all samples, comprising the first report of this yeast as a common
inhabitant in marine sponges. Other yeasts isolated include the
halophilic black yeast, Hortaea werneckii, and an unidentified species
belonging to the Sporidiobolales (Basidiomycota). The high frequency of
isolation of S. cerevisiae from our sponge samples supports the
possibility that Saccharomyces cerevisiae as an active member of the
sponges microbial community.
